video.title: Python Backend Web Development Course (with Django)
video.description:
This video is a full backend web development course with python. In the course, you will learn everything you need to know to start your web development journey with Python and Django.

✏️ Course developed by CodeWithTomi. Check out his channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/CodeWithTomi
🔗 Join CodeWithTomi's Discord Server: https://discord.gg/cjqNBHHhKV
🔗 Twitter: https://twitter.com/TomiTokko3

🔗 Download All Free Resources - https://codewithtomi.eo.page/mz396

Projects Built:
1. A Blog
💻 https://github.com/tomitokko/django-blog
2. A Weather App
💻 https://github.com/tomitokko/weather_detector
3. A Realtime Chat App
💻 https://github.com/tomitokko/django-chat-app

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️

topLevelComment.text: It's not an easy thing to do, but thanks for including the mistakes or even admitting when some of the code doesn't work, even when you know it should work... I'm referring mostly to the section about IDLE, and even though I've used IDLE quite a bit already and i'm used to the indentations and what IDLE will accept etc, it's cool to know that you are teaching us on our level, or a little above our current level, and i'm sure many people will take confidence in knowing that things sometimes just don't work out on the first try and it takes quite a while sometimes for certain concepts to become clear to us! I abandoned learning Python for a few months because of this, and i'm happy to be back now coding with it, and i'm happy to have come across your tutorial. You've done very good work ! I believe I speak for all of us when we are indebted to you for this teaching. Thanks.

replies.author: Mr. Lose Streaks
replies.text:
FOR WINDOWS:
To create new environment:
py -m pip install --user virtualenv

To activate it:
py -m venv "your project name"

Then:
.\your project name\Scripts\activate

That should do it. Your project name should appear next to the command prompt.

replies.text:
FOR WINDOWS:
To create new environment:
py -m pip install --user virtualenv

To activate it:
py -m venv "your project name"

Then:
.\your project name\Scripts\activate

That should do it. Your project name should appear next to the command prompt.

replies.author: Saieswari Amaran
replies.text:
Try following this, it many solve your problem:
In your settings.py (inside the 'myproject' directory, set your TEMPLATES DIRS as 
'DIRS' : [BASE_DIR / 'templates'] instead of 'DIRS' : [BASE_DIR, 'templates']. The latter will cause you to restart your server again and again if any changes made in any .py files.

replies.author: Mr. Lose Streaks
replies.text:
FOR WINDOWS:
To create new environment:
py -m pip install --user virtualenv

To activate it:
py -m venv "your project name"

Then:
.\your project name\Scripts\activate

That should do it. Your project name should appear next to the command prompt..

replies.author: Ken Adams
replies.text:
For Python 3.3 or newer, Commands for installing, creating and activate virtual environment has been changed.

You can install virtual environment using pip:

py -m pip install --user virtualenv
For creating new environment:

py -m venv myproject
To activate your virtual environment:

.\myproject\Scripts\activate
After activating virtual environment, You’ll see “(myproject)” next to the command prompt.
